entry.title: SAP PAPM - the role of business calculation engine in a business steering
entry.content:
Picture 1. End-to-end profitability and performance management

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organization is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organizational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognizing these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organizational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organizations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support ‚Äì going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC 
  4. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. SAP PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering (THIS BLOG POST)
  9. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

In today‚Äôs fast-paced business environment, enterprises must be flexible and adaptable to evolving market conditions and customer expectations. As a result, companies are developing strategies focused on innovation, digital transformation, and sustainable growth. However, when it comes to execution, the benefits of these strategic initiatives often fall short of expectations.

Why the Gap?

Several factors contribute to the disconnect between strategy and execution:

  • Insufficient analysis and adaptation to business changes, making strategies difficult to execute in real-world conditions.
  • Weak integration between financial and operational models, leading to misaligned decisions.
  • Lack of trust in the numbers due to data silos and overly complex reporting models.
  • Poor visibility into root causes of performance, whether underperformance or overachievement.

This is where the concept of Enterprise Performance Management (EPM) becomes critical. EPM serves as the bridge between strategic goals and day-to-day execution. SAP offers a comprehensive, end-to-end EPM framework that spans planning, consolidation, tax, and sustainability management.

Despite advancements, organizations still face hurdles in their EPM processes, that are highly connected to the reasons for the gap between strategy and execution:

  • New regulations and market dynamics
  • Data  silos and disconnected processes
  • Limited business context in performance reporting

To address these, companies increasingly need a business semantics calculation engine as an important part of their EPM framework ‚Äîa solution that connects transactional and planning data to management reporting in real time. Such an engine should enable:

  • Business-user-driven modeling through a no-code/low-code environment
  • Integration of business semantics (e.g., cost allocations, profitability logic) into real-time calculations, powered by solutions like SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Simulation and scenario analysis without IT dependency

Let‚Äôs explore how a business semantics calculation engine can bring value across different scenarios not only for actuals, but also for planning data:

  • Regulatory reporting: Ensure compliance with traceable, rule-based calculations.
  • Profitability analysis: Evaluate performance by customer segment, region, channel, or product line.
  • Bill of Materials (BOM) simulation and explosion: Assess the impact of changing prices or quantities on semi-finished and final products.
  • Operational transfer pricing: Maintain compliance and transparency in cross-border pricing models.
  • Group cost calculations: Enable unified and transparent cost modeling across entities.

For instance, in a BOM simulation, users can assess how price or quantity changes at the component level affect the cost of the final product. This often involves recursive, high-volume calculations. By using SAP S/4HANA for transactional data, enriching it with SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM), and feeding the results into SAP Analytics Cloud, businesses can maintain full transparency, auditability, and planning granularity.

Another example: planned profitability calculations at the SKU level. While this level of detail may be unnecessary in the core budgeting process, it's critical for management reporting. Rather than overburdening the core planning system, businesses can offload these complex calculations to a dedicated engine and integrate the results seamlessly.

Last but not the least example to illustrate the need in business calculation engine is a group costing calculation. Let's say the company has many intercompany relationships, products and services are going through various steps between companies in this process. SAP PAPM delivers real-time insights into group margin, through segmented profit and loss reports according to key transfer pricing dimensions, providing needed data to manage and analyze tax costs and revenues, markups and markup costs, production and services costs and third-party revenues.

Benefits of Embedding a Calculation Engine into the Planning Process

  • Automate complex allocations and business logic
  • Ensure full transparency and auditability
  • Enable granular planning and analysis‚Äîby customer, product, channel, etc.
  • Increase compliance by following new regulations

From the business user‚Äôs perspective, this process should be seamless. As a planner, you simply run the calculation and see results immediately integrated into your planning reports. This is precisely the kind of user-centric experience enabled by the SAP EPM framework‚Äîcombining SAP S/4HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM).

Picture 2. Detailed Profitability analysis powered by SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP PAPM

WHAT IS SAP PAPM? 

SAP PaPM Cloud is a no-code calculation engine that empowers business users to model and execute complex logic without IT intervention. It processes large data volumes at high speed and supports a wide range of EPM scenarios.

Key capabilities include:

  • Extending standardized processes in SAP S/4HANA with custom logic and allocations
  • Enabling business users to model complex rules without coding
  • Processing massive data sets in-memory via SAP HANA
  • Integrating data from SAP and non-SAP sources, hosted on SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Creating financial documents, postings to general or group ledger, and more in SAP S/4HANA enabling an end-to-end process, and not just running as a disconnected calculation engine
  • Ensuring full traceability from results to source data

Picture 3. SAP Profitability and Performance Management

SAP PAPM and SAP BUSINESS DATA CLOUD

SAP PAPM can on top of BDC, in this case data persistency and processing happens on the SAP Datasphere level in SAP BDC. With SAP BDC Data products we can ensure context-rich data from SAP and non- SAP sources being available for PAPM calculations, building a foundation for detailed transparent analysis and also providing even more data for AI-powered insights.  Another benefit of placing SAP PAPM on top of SAP BDC is that with SAC being also part of the platform, we can really ensure end-to-end EPM processes without data replication, leveraging seamless planning and when needed extending calculations with SAP PAPM engine to achieve even greater transparency and performance.  Ream more about BDC components in our previous blog "Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)"

Picture 4. SAP Business Data Cloud components

Let‚Äôs take a look at the data flow for a corporate profitability analysis within an SAP landscape.
The initial data originates in the transactional system or system of record, SAP S/4HANA. While S/4HANA already provides capabilities for cost calculation and allocation, we can further enrich this data with performance results and details‚Äîsuch as customer segment, region, channel, or product line‚Äîand incorporate simulations.

To achieve this, we introduce an additional BDC-based layer that leverages BDC data products and SAP Datasphere to connect to S/4HANA, as well as other potential data sources and prepare the data. SAP PaPM then performs the calculations, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) visualizes the results and provides a planning-process framework for end users.

Picture 5. Corporate profitability analysis with SAP solutions

Conclusion

A business semantics calculation engine is a powerful tool in enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of EPM processes. Whether it‚Äôs for tax, transfer pricing, profitability modelling, or planning enhancements, SAP Profitability and Performance Management plays an important role in bridging the gap between transactional data and reporting requirements.

By embedding SAP PaPM within your EPM architecture, you can equip business users to act even faster, have greater insights, and align execution more closely with strategic intent. SAP Business Data cloud will provide a proven semantically reach data foundation and AI tools to simplify analysis, we will be giving more detailed examples in our next articles. 

Looking to take the next step? Connect with your SAP representative to register for an SAP BDC Discovery Workshop.
To expand your expertise in SAP PaPM, consider exploring the related blog series published within the SAP Community  and stay tuned for more.

entry.title: Re: ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Hi @radhika_javvaji , @KevinSong 

My issue is now resolved. The proxy objects were there but under a different bucket. I followed steps below:

1- Run t-code SPROXY.

2- Goto menu Utilities --> Settings

3- Scroll to the tab Proxy Generation and change the Enterprise Service Browser setting to "D Enterprise Service Browser"

4- Back out and re-run SPROXY. 

5- Follow node Source --> ESR --> SWCs and you will see your custom integration packages there.

Note:- Choose Re-usable option while migrating your SAP PO interfaces to integration suite. Otherwise, no objects will be created in the backend.

Hope it helps.

Regards,

Kamran

entry.title: Vendor Automatically Changes to Head Office Vendor During Supplier Invoice Posting in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are working on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud 3SL in India localization.

Our supplier has multiple GST registrations across different states, so we created one vendor BP for each GSTIN (branch vendors). We also have one Head Office (HO) Vendor with bank details, which is maintained as the Alternative Payee for payment run purposes. This is aligned with GST design.

Expected SAP Standard Behaviour

Invoices (PO-based & non-PO) must always post to the branch vendor, because GST reporting is state-specific.

Only the APP payment run should redirect payment to the HO Vendor via Alternative Payee.

Issue We Are Facing

During supplier invoice posting (Create Supplier Invoice / MIRO equivalent), even after selecting the branch vendor, SAP automatically replaces the vendor with the HO vendor.

The system shows:

‚ÄúAccount has been changed: dependent data will be initialised.‚Äù

The invoice is finally posted to the HO vendor, which is incorrect for GST and vendor reconciliation.

What We Have Already Validated

No custom logic exists in Custom Logic (BAdI) app

PO is created with the correct branch vendor

Branch vendor has no bank details

HO Vendor is maintained only as Alternative Payee

No extensions are influencing vendor fields

Questions to the Community

Is this automatic replacement of vendor during invoice posting standard behaviour in S/4HANA Public Cloud 3SL?

Does Alternative Payee affect invoice posting, or only the payment run?

Could this be caused by BP Partner Functions (FLVN01 ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Partner Functions)?

Should SSCUI 102561 (Partner Determination for Supplier) or 102617 (Supplier Account Groups) be checked for default partner assignments?

What is the correct SAP recommended configuration for multi-GST vendor scenarios where invoice must post to branch vendor and payment must go to HO vendor?

We need a confirmation from SAP experts because invoice posting to HO vendor breaks GST compliance and vendor-level ageing.

 

Thanks in advance for your guidance.

entry.title: Re: Implementing BAPI_CONTRACT_CHANGE
entry.content:
@FabioMendona

Fabio,

We did this change for BAPI_PO_CHANGE

We did not implement any other BADIs or Exits, but, an existing user exit was posing a problem. EXIT_SAPMM06E_016

It was not a problem in ECC but in S4 it was. Had to add this as first block in user exit.

IF i_no_screen EQ abap_true "Called by Function ( BAPI )
   OR i_aktyp EQ 'A'.

  " This is being called by a Function module ( BAPI ) or Called in Dialog in Display mode
  " During display, data derivation should not happen

  ekpo_ci = CORRESPONDING ekpo_ci( i_ekpo ).

  RETURN.

ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: Review Customer Projects - Business Requirement: Peri...
entry.content:
Dear @bangaru198251,

below is a proposal of your requirements and available functionalities in the Public Cloud system, while maintaining the clean-core and Cloud-friendly.

Story 1

Plan monthly effort in hours, use Plan Customer Projects

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F0719')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/21218854c46ee75ee10000000a44176d.html

  • For each work package /role you can see availability per month and manually redistribute effort across periods of the work package (months in your case)
  • That gives you a true time-phased baseline for effort and thus planned costs (since planned cost = hours √ó cost rate)

Run the monthly forecast review, use Review Customer Projects + Set Forecast Month:

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/1a8fa3529556495592a29cdda3f70824.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/2c41db55e8187816e10000000a44538d.html

How variance is handled

SAP standard logic when you set / change the forecast month is:

  • Variances between planned and actual efforts and expenses before the new forecast month are plugged into the forecast month rather than being spread automatically across future months

So the system does calculate variance, but it concentrates it in the forecast month, not distributed into all remaining months

Get the forecast into Finance by period

Use Transfer Project Forecast to Finance:

  • This job takes the confirmed forecast from Review Customer Projects and creates / updates CO plan data in Finance, time-phased by period
  • Unlike Review Customer Projects, it looks at all actuals, not only up to the forecast month

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/5d577318fb924200877a167566837e81.html

Story 2

How cost rates work in Public Cloud

  • Manage Cost Rates Services
    Define cost rates for professional services for combinations like: company code, receiving cost center, activity type, service cost level, employee (personnel number), work item and even WBS element

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/9fca5b12d8df4591a240100305da6357.html

  • Manage Cost Rates Plan
    Maintain planned activity prices by period (fiscal year/month) and ledger; these feed planning and (depending on set-up) can be used as the standard rate during the period

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/bd39911453324bf7900cccb4531e206e.html

  • Manage Cost Rates Actual
    Store actual cost rates, manually or via Actual Cost Rate Calculation at period end. These override the other rates if maintained

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/10c16133145f4f0ca9be1e9e3e4a6cdd.html

All these apps support time-dependency

Story 3

This is where standard functionality diverges from your requirement.

  • Employees record time using Manage My Timesheet
  • In the Professional Services scenario, process steps include:
    • Record time
    • Approve timesheet entries
    • Transfer time recordings to target components

Key points:

  • Once a time entry is transferred to CO/Project, cost is posted immediately based on the cost rate determination

SAP Note with details:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002951857

  • You can back post time into past periods as long as FI/CO periods are open so Timesheet entries can be posted for past periods when rates become available is standard

This means:

    • You do see provisional cost during the month.
    • But the final period cost equals hours √ó final rate, without needing to buffer hours.
    • Revenue recognition in customer projects already works with dynamic/confirmed EAC logic and will adjust PoC based on updated costs

Side-by-side BTP extension

If your business requirement is truly absolutely no cost postings before rate approval, you‚Äôd need a side-by-side design

Story 4

Standard month-end sequence

  1. Close time and billing for the month
    • Ensure timesheets are complete and transferred
    • Run project billing as needed
  2. Set Forecast Month
    • Use Set Forecast Month to set the current closed month as the forecast reference.
    • This controls which actuals are shown in Review Customer Projects and how previous variances are rolled into the forecast month

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/1a8fa3529556495592a29cdda3f70824.html

  1. Review Customer Projects
  2. Transfer Project Forecast to Finance
    • Run the job so that your updated forecast is written into time-phased financial plan data

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/29cf986299714386847f4d4c9bb86994/5d577318fb924200877a167566837e81.html

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-blog-posts-by-sap/financial-planned-data-in-professional-services-by-project-financial/ba-p/14241364

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/89d896ca9cd64318b1667df5ec00e4b2/5e6d33c7a74d4c528d496dde89c8957c.html

  1. Repeat next month
    • Next month, set the forecast month forward and repeat the cycle so you‚Äôre literally working sequentially month by month.

Summary:

  • Story 1 and 4 can be covered with standard Public Cloud (Professional Services) using: Plan Customer Projects, Review Customer Projects, Set Forecast Month and Transfer Project Forecast to Finance
  • Story 2 time-dependent rates are fully standard via Manage Cost Rates Services / Plan / Actual. The system works with validity periods and rate overrides (even down to WBS)
  • Story 3 the hold hours until rates exist, then post once is not how Public Cloud works in standard

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: üá∞üáº Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core (Doha, QA)
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core with Python. You don't need any prior background in the topic, but you should have a strong curiosity and basic coding skills.

In this SAP CodeJam, you will learn how to use Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement a retrieval augmented generation (RAG) use case to improve the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduce hallucinations. You will learn how to work with LLMs and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core and query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Furthermore, you will learn about the most important genAI concepts and create and use embeddings to improve your RAG response and build your own chatbot with memory. 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual, no streaming) and is planned for Wednesday, December 10, 2025, from 10:00 to 16:00 local time. The event's language and content will be in English. 

The event is being hosted by Mark9 at
Regus, D-Ring Road,
Al Mataar / Al Qadeem District, Doha

Prerequisites: Bring your own laptop with a Chromium-based web browser, such as Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, etc.

Please note that seating is limited to 20 seats and is available on a first-come, first-served basis.

entry.title: Re: splitting 100000 records to two internal tables and post in al11
entry.content:
If I understand you correctly you have one internal table with 100k entries and you want to split them into 2 internal tables with 50k entries each?

If my assumption is correct you can do a very basic approach of looping at the main table and utilizing SY-INDEX variable as a index(er) (or create a index variable yourself - which you have to increase inside the loop. Add a IF statement that checks wether or not the current index is below 50k or above and distribute the data accordingly. Either you just move data from the original iTab to a second iTab or move data from the original one to iTab1 at counter < 50k and into iTab2 when counter > 50k. The LOOP AT structure allows you to either use a field symbol (for performance optimization) or work area. I would suggest you use the field-symbol approach since it is generally faster (due to the lack of the need for memory allocation) since you are working with a field symbol instead of moving data from the tab to a work area.

There are also other methods that involve more advanced language features like the VALUE keyword but depending on your needs sometimes the easiest option is jus the best. If you want "the best" option you'd need to supply a bit more information.

Hope it helps and: happy coding!

Edit: I overlooked the mentioning of AL11 in the title, do you wish to split the original table into 2 and export this into a file (with a certain format)? If so it would help tremendously if you could specify a bit more what the output format should be. I imagine you need some sort of CSV format? For that the easiest way would be to use OPEN DATASET, but again: more details needed üòÖ

According to Help Guide https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/managing-sap-successfactors-user-experience/creating-or-editing-custom-cards-for-home-page?version=2511&q=date+range+Based+on+start+date+custom+card the Date Range works to specify a date range when the card is shown and the Based on Start Date to show the card in relation to a person's start date. Kind Regards,

Cristian

//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//The data region against which the formulas will be executed.
//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
MEMBERSET [d/PSPELEMENT] = BASEMEMBER([d/PSPELEMENT].[h/PSPHIER], %PSPElemBaseMember%)
MEMBERSET [d/Date] = %STARTDATUM% TO %ENDDATUM%
MEMBERSET [d/Parametertyp] = "100"

//-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
//Calculation and Data Writing

MODEL [APC_BASIC_DATA]
ENDMODEL

FOREACH [d/PERSONAL], [APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM] ASC
	IF DATEDIFF([d/Date], [APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM], "MONTH") >= 0 THEN
		IF LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000") > 0 THEN

			DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "STUNDEN") * LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000")

		ENDIF
	ENDIF

The purpose of this function is to find the correct hourly rate for each data record in the main model and then to calculate the revenue.

The FOREACH should check for each employee and validfrom whether the month of the current record in the main model is greater than or equal to the validfrom month of the linked model. By sorting in ascending order, I ensure that the hourly rate with the largest validfrom month is calculated last and that each hour is calculated with the correct hourly rate.

The problem is that the LINK command within the FOREACH does not take the validfrom value of the current iteration. It seems as if it takes the aggregation of all hourly rates for an employee.

How can I specify the filter for the validfrom dimension of the current iteration in the LINK command?

entry.title: Re: How to reference child object in another custom MDF o...

Hi syeapAB,

 

According to KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003383815 it is not recommended to configure a child object in another MDF Object as a Generic Object reference field and the system will throw the error message you received.

But the data updating from UI (manage data, people profile.etc) may work, however, it may not work for MDF import / Odata API scenarios to update MDF data, the Odata API updating or the MDF import will fail.

 

Regards,

Cristian

entry.title: TechEd Recap: Creating AI-Enhanced UX for Your Own Applications with SAP Design System
entry.content:
By Sophia Levens and Thomas Reiss

We were thrilled to speak at this year‚Äôs TechEd conference in Berlin on how the SAP Design System is powering the next generation of AI-led product design. Our Deep Dive talk entitled ‚ÄúCreating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System‚Äù focused on three key areas: an introduction into the SAP Design System, new AI patterns for the design system and SAPUI5, and our AI-powered tools for our UI technologies. We then closed the session with an overview of the resources available to designers and developers today.

Below we‚Äôll share a recap of the major points and announcements from the session. You can also watch the recorded session here.

 

Introduction to the SAP Design System

The overall mission of the SAP Design System is to unify and advance the SAP user experience. We achieve this in two ways:

  • Unify: The SAP Design System serves as the central hub of ready-to-use assets, guidance and standards for building delightful experiences that are consistent across the SAP portfolio. This is how we directly contribute to SAP‚Äôs Suite-First strategy.
  • Advance: The SAP Design System provides the essential patterns and tools to embed transformative AI experiences across all products and touchpoints. This is how we directly contribute to the AI-First goal.

What exactly is a design system?

In order to deliver consistent and inclusive UX, the SAP Design System is made up of the following elements:

  1. Design Language: The most foundational elements that go into any brand. For example, color, type, iconography, illustrations, etc.
  2. Components: The building blocks for creating user interfaces, like buttons, drop down menus, or input fields.
  3. Patterns: Covers a use case or user flow, things like exporting data to PDF or a search workflow.
  4. Floorplans: A full UI layout. Typically, floorplans are a complete page or even span several pages.

The SAP Design System extends across SAP. It helps to unify all touchpoints across the SAP brand including our products, our digital experiences like sap.com, and other marketing and communications including interactive events like TechEd. And because the system is open source, our customers can also use the design system to build upon and customize our products and platforms.

What UI technologies are supported with the SAP Design System?

For each element in the SAP Design System, we build reusable components in code that developers can leverage to accelerate their workflow. There are two ways to leverage SAP technologies‚Äîvia ‚Äúfloorplans and building blocks‚Äù or ‚Äúfreestyle‚Äù.

  • Build ‚Äúfreestyle‚Äù with SAPUI5 and SAP Web Components: Freestyle allows you full control of every element on the screen.
  • Use ‚Äúfloorplans and building blocks‚Äù with SAP Fiori Elements: This lets you accelerate development when the desired app or workflow is close to one of the out-of-the box floorplans or building blocks.

Because both of these choices are based on SAPUI5, you don‚Äôt have to choose one or the other, you can mix both ways of developing leveraging each when needed.

 

New AI Patterns for the SAP Design System and SAPUI5

SAP is proud to offer AI components and patterns for web and mobile. We‚Äôre investing in making it easy to design and build great AI experiences that are responsible, flexible, and work across ecosystems. Our AI experience principles are built on the following six pillars: design for clarity, earn trust, give control, design fairly, boost flow, fail-safe.

Find the latest AI patterns and components:

  • SAP Design System portal
  • SAP Web UI Kit
  • SAP Fiori for iOS UI Kit
  • SAP Fiori for Android UI Kit
  • UI5 Web Components

Our AI components and patterns have gone through the process of reviews and testing by our experts in user assistance, accessibility, user research, and are compliant with SAP‚Äôs legal and ethical AI standards. These are patterns you and your users can trust.

 

Using our AI-powered UI Technologies to Help You Build Faster

We have introduced powerful AI tools to help you build UIs and applications faster.

SAP Joule for Developers is a collection of embedded AI capabilities for SAP Build as well as for ABAP, delivered through Joule, that accelerates development of apps and extensions, reduces costs, and improves developer proficiency.

The SAP Fiori tools project accelerator, which can be started from Joule in SAP Build Code, enables developers to create CAP-based (Cloud Application Programming model based) SAP Fiori elements applications directly from an image of the intended outcome. These images can be high fidelity Figma models, lower fidelity screenshots or a sketch on paper. Simply upload the image and use AI to generate the data models, services and the UI. Find out more in this blog post: From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps.

 Generate a complete CAP-based application from a sketch with SAP Fiori tools project accelerator: data models, services and UI.

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers equip developers with valuable support by providing AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information.

Read about the new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Key Takeaways

This deep dive session gave an overview of how customers and partners can create AI-enhanced UX for their own applications with the SAP Design System and SAP‚Äôs UI technologies. Find everything you need to get started designing and developing:

  • Get started with the SAP Design System portal.
  • Use SAP's UI kits with the new AI patterns.
  • Use SAPUI5.

entry.title: Re: SolMan 7.2 RFC unable to set to confirmed in producti...
entry.content:
To limit this situation from happening again, I suggest configuring the predecessor-successor status attributes (Specify Status Attributes) so the incident status cannot be confirmed until the successor RFC is confirmed, or whatever status values your business case requires. For example, we've configured the incident transaction so that before it can be set to Proposed Solution, the successor RFC must have one of the statuses, Implemented, Confirmed, or Withdrawn.

Proceed with caution: But, to update an RFC where the predecessor incident is already closed, you might consider using the report, CRM_SOCM_SERVICE_REPORT. Please read the fine documentation for the report. This report can update the status of a transaction (or set of transactions), but will not make the consistency checks built into the application. Be sure of what you're about to do, and use the "List Output Only (No Update)" option to check the selected transaction(s), etc., before committing updates.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New for Joule in SAP Fieldglass ‚Äì November 2025
entry.content:
Joule in SAP Fieldglass was first introduced in July, and since then its capabilities have continued to expand. Our latest November 2025 release brings several key enhancements designed to streamline processes, boost efficiency, and improve accessibility and inclusivity for users globally.

What‚Äôs New for Joule in the SAP Fieldglass November 2025 Release:

  • Multi-Language Support
    Joule can now automatically detect the user‚Äôs input language, interacting and responding in the user‚Äôs preferred language

 

  • Translated Templates and Report Retrieval
    For organizations that translate Job Posting Templates, SOW Templates, and Reports, Joule will identify the user‚Äôs preferred language and retrieve the corresponding localized version when available.

 

  •  Simplified Job Posting Template Recommendations
    Users can now describe their needs in natural language. Joule will interpret the requirement and retrieve relevant templates‚Äîremoving the previous dependency on specific job titles.

 

  • Decision Form Approvals
    Users can now approve or reject Decision Forms directly within Joule when reviewing their pending Work Items, making the approval process faster and more intuitive.

 

  • Legal Entity Recognition
    When Legal Entity functionality is enabled, users can include the Legal Entity as part of their requirements when creating Job Postings or Statements of Work. Joule will recognize and automatically populate the correct value in the appropriate documents.

Want to Learn More?

Watch our short Joule Release Highlights video demonstrating these items.

Explore our Joule in SAP Fieldglass Help Portal page for a comprehensive overview of the tool and its current capabilities.

Visit the SAP Community for additional release resources and the latest AI insights.

entry.title: Adoption Isn‚Äôt a Phase, It‚Äôs a Relationship
entry.content:
If you know me, you know I love an analogy. It‚Äôs always helpful to make new information make sense by likening it to something we already understand.

In my role here at SAP, I talk about adoption a lot. It‚Äôs a point that I (and my wonderful team, Solution Value Advisory) really push with our customers, who sometimes think of adoption as a step in the overall process, something you do after go-live.  So, my analogy for today is to look at adoption like a relationship, because it‚Äôs never just about the software, but about the people and how they interact with the system and each other.

It‚Äôs not much of a stretch, really. At the start, it‚Äôs a mix of excitement, a little confusion, and commitment that comes with bringing something new into your life, and hoping it thrives, grows, and has the support of people around you.


The honeymoon stage
 In my last role several years back, I worked on Ariba solution implementations. Being on a shared services team, I got to stick my hands into a lot of different customers‚Äô Ariba deployments. It felt great, for the customer and for me, to reach what felt like a finish line: go-live. That point of the new solution(s) going live after months of setup and testing. The vibes were always good - everyone was hopeful, users explored the system, performed tests. Teams got trained. There was that spark of possibility, that sense of this time, things will be different.

But just like any new relationship, the shine fades if the day-to-day connection isn‚Äôt nurtured. Old habits creep back in, shortcuts resurface. And, before long, that beautiful new tool starts gathering dust.  Remember, adoption doesn‚Äôt end at go-live, that‚Äôs when it begins.


Relationships thrive on consistency, and so do systems
Healthy adoption looks a lot like a healthy partnership: steady, intentional, and full of small moments that build trust.

It‚Äôs when someone logs in and sees that their preferences were remembered. It‚Äôs when data syncs across systems, so people stop fighting with spreadsheets and endless back-and-forth email. It‚Äôs when users realize the tool makes their jobs easier, not harder. It keeps the relationship alive.

But breakdowns don‚Äôt usually happen with a bang, but a fizzle. Users don‚Äôt revolt, they quietly disengage. They skip the process ‚Äújust this once.‚Äù Then they stop trusting the data, because the process is getting skipped and they can‚Äôt find what they were looking for. And now something that was originally set up to create efficiency is now only causing frustration, and becomes a pain in the‚Ä¶well, you know. üòä

In my work with customers, I see this all the time.  I work a lot with customers on their supplier management processes especially, and I see a lot of this disengagement when it comes to onboarding. Tools like SAP Cloud Identity Services and SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle & Performance (SLP) can be super powerful, but they depend on trusted data and consistency. If people don‚Äôt understand why something matters, they won‚Äôt invest in making it work.

The love language of AI is good data
Now we‚Äôre entering a new chapter, one where AI tools like SAP Joule are ready to help make our jobs easier. But even Joule, which might seem like magic when you see it presented, needs a foundation of trust. This has been my main message of the year - reminding people that AI doesn‚Äôt make magic out of thin air, rather it builds on what we give it. If data is messy, disconnected, or if established processes are underused, Joule‚Äôs insights will be, too.

(Pausing here for a shoutout to anyone who was at the Customer Success Day in NYC earlier this year where I did a whole session to essentially say, ‚ÄúGarbage in, garbage out‚Äù. The highlight, at least to me, was my AI-generated Ariba song parody of Naughty by Nature‚Äôs O.P.P.  Who‚Äôs down with SLP? Yeah you know me!)

But back to my relationship analogy, think of it this way: if you never talk to your partner, you can‚Äôt expect them to finish your sentences. Joule works the same way. The relationship only deepens when we communicate through connected, clean, and well-adopted systems. 


Adoption is ongoing care.
As I said before, adoption isn‚Äôt a task. We don‚Äôt ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù adoption. We maintain it. We check in with our users, we update them on changes, and we listen when something isn‚Äôt working and adjust before resentment sets in.  The most successful customers I see are those who treat adoption as a living process. Not just implementing technology, but inviting it into their company culture. When adoption is healthy, everything else (innovation, automation, AI, etc.) starts to flow naturally.  But just like any great relationship, it takes attention, empathy, and patience.


I encourage you all to stay in tune with our roadmap, as there‚Äôs a lot of exciting stuff to come in 2026 when it comes to AI in SAP. But as you read up on that and start to think how cool it will be and how much time it will save to have all of those new capabilities, remember that now is the time to build the foundation for that new relationship. 

If you have any doubts about how well your company is adopting your solutions and how you‚Äôre doing on usage in comparison to other customers, do reach out to your CSM who can either help, or can pull in the right people to have that conversation. Sometimes that person is me, so say hi and maybe I'll share my library of Ariba song parodies.

entry.title: Re: sac advanced formula - searching for the right record...
entry.content:
Shortly after writing the post, I found the solution. 

1. My DATEDIFF function was defined incorrectly.

2. The aggregation did not come via the LINK command but is contained in the DATA statement.

Here is the corrected code:

MODEL [APC_BASIC_DATA]
ENDMODEL

FOREACH [d/PERSONAL], [APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM] ASC
	IF DATEDIFF([APC_BASIC_DATA].[d/VALIDFROM], [d/Date], "MONTH") >= 0 THEN
		IF LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000") > 0 THEN

			DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz") = 0
			DATA([d/Measures] = "Umsatz") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "STUNDEN") * LINK([APC_BASIC_DATA], [d/Measures] = "Betrag", [d/PSPELEMENT] = %PSPElemQuelle%, [d/Parametertyp] = "1", [d/Version] = "public.Actual", [d/Date] = "000000")

		ENDIF
	ENDIF
ENDFOR

kind regards,
Max

entry.title: SuccessFactors 2H 2025 Release: Smarter Review Flows with New Business Rule Scenario
entry.content:
What‚Äôs New?

SAP SuccessFactors introduces a powerful enhancement via the new feature Business Rules for Performance Management:

New Rule Scenario ‚Äì ‚ÄúAdd Review Steps Upon Form Routing.‚Äù

This capability allows organizations to design dynamic, conditional review processes by automatically inserting additional review steps during form routing ‚Äî based on specific business conditions.

Key Highlights

  • Automated Review Steps: Add one or multiple review steps during the Modify stage of a form.
  • Conditional Visibility: Keep steps hidden until triggered by a business rule.
  • Flexible Criteria: Configure rules based on overall ratings, custom fields, or competency rating.

Business Use Cases

  • If a manager‚Äôs overall rating is above or below a given threshold (e.g. Either at higher or at lower end of the rating scale), an extra reviewer step can be added automatically.
  • For PIP & Confirmation forms, granting an extension can trigger an additional approval step.

How to Configure

  1. Enable the latest Performance Management form experience in Admin Center. The business rule scenario described here works only if the customer has enabled the latest experience of Performance Management forms.
  2. Add relevant steps in the Route Map.
  3. Identify the steps that need to be triggered only when the business rule condition is met.
  4. Mark these steps as Hidden Until Rule Execution in the Route Map.
  5. Create a rule using Add Review Steps Upon Form Routing scenario in Business Rules Admin.
  6. Assign the rule to the Form Routing to Next Step trigger.

Why It Matters

This important enhancement empowers HR and system administrators to create smarter, conditional review flows - fostering fairness, helps eliminate bias, balancing consistency with flexibility in performance management processes that align seamlessly with overarching organizational goals of transparency and impartiality.

Take Action

Performance reviews should adapt to your business needs. With this new rule scenario, you can make your process intelligent and responsive.

Start configuring today and experience the difference!

SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals SAP SuccessFactors HCM Core SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite

entry.title: Turning SAP Data into Process Intelligence: The Future of Seamless Connectivity
entry.content:
Every transformation journey starts with one question: Can I truly trust the data that drives my decisions?

For many SAP customers, the answer depends on how easily and reliably process-relevant data can move from core ERP systems into the analytical layer. Until now, that often meant complex setups, manual extractions, and limited scalability.
But that‚Äôs changing.

A New Era of Data Replication
With SAP Datasphere replication flows, SAP customers can now connect SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA systems directly to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence with even more efficiency - turning operational data into actionable insight at enterprise scale.

Mass extraction of SAP data with SAP Datasphere replication flows

Why It Matters
In process transformation, speed and reliability are everything. Organizations need to see how their processes actually run - not last month, but right now. By leveraging SAP Datasphere‚Äôs built-in replication and Change Data Capture (CDC) capabilities, businesses can ensure continuous, near real-time synchronization of their SAP data landscape, having their data automatically updated in SAP Signavio Process Intelligence.

The result?

  • Faster insights: Data from SAP systems flows instantly into SAP Signavio Process Intelligence for mining and monitoring.
  • Proven reliability: Built on SAP-standard connectivity, it ensures compliance, governance, and peace of mind.
  • True scalability: Whether you run SAP ECC, SAP S/4HANA on-prem, private, or public cloud ‚Äî it grows with your transformation journey.

Simplicity Meets Power
By reusing the SAP standard connectivity (e.g. SAP Cloud Connector), the integration offers a clean, standardized setup. No additional approval and implementation needed for Signavio dedicated connectivity. No data staging. Just smooth, direct data replication, monitored and managed through SAP Datasphere‚Äôs transparent interface and a future-proof way to bring data to life.


Empowering Continuous Transformation
When your process data is always current, your insights are always relevant. This is what makes SAP Datasphere replication flows more than a connectivity upgrade: it‚Äôs a strategic foundation for data-driven transformation.
Together, SAP Datasphere and SAP Signavio Process Intelligence empower organizations to turn system data into business truth, helping leaders make faster, smarter decisions with confidence.

In short, SAP Datasphere replication flows are redefining how SAP customers move from data to insight ‚Äî unlocking reliability, scalability, and transparency across the enterprise.


It‚Äôs not just integration.
It‚Äôs connection with purpose.

 

Click here to start a step-by-step enable now tutorial for this feature.

entry.title: The Added Value of SAP Business Data Cloud with Databricks, Snowflake and MS Fabric
entry.content:
There as been a lot of partnership announcement lately broadening the extend of SAP Business Data Cloud capabilities and integration.

In today‚Äôs multi-platform data landscapes, organizations are increasingly blending SAP and non-SAP data to drive insights, automate decision-making, and accelerate innovation. But combining the trusted semantics of SAP with the scalability and flexibility of modern cloud data platforms is not always straightforward.
This is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)‚Äîpowered by SAP Datasphere‚Äîdelivers extraordinary strategic value. And with BDC connect, SAP takes cross-ecosystem integration even further, enabling a harmonized, governed, bidirectional data fabric that works seamlessly with platforms such as Microsoft Fabric, Snowflake, and Databricks.

Why SAP Business Data Cloud Changes the Game

SAP Business Data Cloud is designed to bridge the historical gap between SAP‚Äôs rich business context and the broader data landscape. It moves beyond simple data replication or extraction: it preserves SAP‚Äôs business semantics, delivers harmonized models, and enables federated consumption with minimal data movement, to take on-time decisions based on data.

Here‚Äôs what makes it transformative:

1. Business-ready data out of the box

SAP systems contain deeply embedded logic‚Äîcurrency conversions, hierarchies, master data relationships, authorizations, time-dependencies‚Äînone of which carry over when raw tables are moved into a data lake or modern warehouse.

Throughts Business Data Cloud, SAP provides out-of-the box Data Products that automatically collects and exposes SAP data with meaning intact, avoiding:

  • custom semantic reconstruction

  • brittle pipelines

  • manual hierarchical transformations

This dramatically reduces time-to-insight for downstream analytics platforms.

2. Governance, lineage, and security at enterprise scale

BDC maintains:

  • end-to-end lineage

  • SAP role-based security

  • metadata enrichment

  • business catalogs

This ensures that downstream platforms consume trusted, governed data, not raw or misinterpreted tables.

How BDC combines with Microsoft Fabric, Snowflake, and Databricks

While SAP Business Data Cloud is a fully standalone powerful platform for data and analytics, customers may have chosen another technology to handle some aspects of their data storage and governance. Providing a partnership with these platforms enables to propose a deep integration within a broader ecosystem.

üìò SAP Business Data Cloud + Microsoft Fabric

With BDC connect, Fabric can tap directly into SAP semantic models with a zero-copy capabilities enabling to successfully combine SAP and non-SAP data and leverging the existing features of Microfot Fabric.

‚ùÑÔ∏è SAP Business Data Cloud + Snowflake

Snowflake excels at multi-cloud elasticity, secure data sharing, and workload isolation. BDC complements Snowflake through:

  • SAP-optimized data contracts exposed as Snowflake-ready datasets

  • Replication or federation with preserved semantics

  • Accelerated development of Snowflake Data Cloud applications using SAP-trusted data

Here too, the BDC Connect capabilities enables to do a zero-copy sharing of the data, avoiding data replication and keeping the context of the data..

üî• SAP Business Data Cloud + Databricks

Databricks is the leader in lakehouse architecture, ML/AI workloads, and open data formats. With BDC:

  • Data scientists gain business-aware SAP data without reverse-engineering SAP logic

  • ML models can be trained on harmonized SAP+non-SAP datasets

  • Semantic consistency is maintained from source to model consumption

  • Unity Catalog benefits from SAP lineage and metadata

BDC connect enables bi-directional zero-copy interoperability, including pushing curated datasets back into analytics or operational systems.

BDC connect: The Integration Accelerator

A core enabler in the ecosystem is BDC connect, providing a streamlined, governed, and high-performance integration zero-copy mechanism between SAP Business Data Cloud and modern data platforms.

With BDC connect, your data platform of choice becomes SAP-aware by design.

To summarize :

BDC ensures your modern data platforms stop treating SAP as just another source, and start treating it as a first-class, business-ready data foundation.

entry.title: Re: Enterprise content Management
entry.content:
Hi,

You‚Äôre right that SAP DMS and SAP ECM are related but not the same. A SAP DMS consultant mainly focuses on Web DMS, Easy DMS, and document handling within SAP. SAP ECM is broader, covering content management, workflows, and enterprise-wide integration.

It‚Äôs not strictly necessary for a DMS consultant to know all of ECM, but understanding it helps, especially when considering integrations with other platforms. Tools like Dokmee can complement SAP DMS/ECM by offering advanced document management, workflow automation, and secure content storage outside SAP.

Warm regards.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud ADT Package deleted
entry.content:
Hi @adnanmaqbool, I do not have much idea about whether it can be recovered from the QAS or production system. but if you have the deleted objects in other systems. you can shift them to your working system using abapgit. Here are the steps you can perform:

- create a new branch and push all deleted objects to the new branch.
- now in your repository link switch branch to the newly created one (this feature should be there is the newest AbapGit version).
- trigger a pull but while selecting modified objects do not select any removal of existing objects. (this would allow your objects to be pulled to the system with current set of objects).
- after your pull is finished you will have all the deleted objects and your existing objects together. As for objects with inconsistencies, I can't say if this approach will help that case as well.

Best Regards,
Aarnav

entry.title: Scanning the storage bin's barcode S4H public cloud
entry.content:
Hello,

The client requires that when they change/confirm the storage bin of an HU using the RF device, the barcode in the warehouse is scanned to identify the storage bin. This code being the storage bin verification code, which is different from the storage bin code.

This happen when performing a goods receipt from a vendor and also when transferring a Handling Unit (HU) to a different storage bin.

This functionality is part of the standard process: the system should use the location verification code as the storage bin code because the user is physically in front of the correct bin. The verification code is intentionally different from the actual storage bin code to prevent users from entering the bin code from anywhere in the warehouse.

It's like 3435076 - Control de verificaci√≥n en /SCWM/RFUI  Note SAP but for 4Shanna public Cloud.

Please let us know if there is any customizing we still need to activate for this to work as intended, or how it should be done.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: Scrapping Materials from Warehouse
entry.content:
Two options are there to meet your requirement.

Option-1

Go with sales order delivery block as suggested already but it has its own limitations which are

  • Delivery Block is a binary control (blocked/unblocked). It doesn‚Äôt support multi‚Äëlevel approvals or workflow like PO release strategy.
  • You will know who removed the block, but you don‚Äôt get structured approval history like in MM release strategy. From audit point of view, this method is weak
  • Introducing customer master data and logistics flows that are irrelevant for scrapping.

Option-2

  • Create a dedicated vendor master (e.g., ‚ÄúSCRAP VENDOR‚Äù) flagged as internal. Configure PO document type specifically for scrapping. Assign account assignment category (e.g., K = Cost Center) to ensure postings hit the correct G/L and cost center. Maintain release strategy for this PO type, so scrapping requests go through approval.
  • Once PO is approved, scrapping can be executed via MIGO against the PO (movement type 551). This will still generate TR/TO, so RF picking remains intact. The warehouse process does not change ‚Äî only the initiation step is controlled via PO release.
  • Finance can monitor scrapping via PO reporting. G/L accounts and cost centers are explicitly controlled in PO account assignment. Audit trail is stronger: PO ‚Üí Release ‚Üí MIGO ‚Üí TR/TO.
  •

entry.title: Automatic reversal functionality after payment rejection
entry.content:
How to activate Auto-reject and reversal of payment batch in SAP S/4HANA public cloud edition.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Automatic reversal functionality after payment rejection
entry.content:
To set Payment Batch to the status "Automatically Rejected" in Public Cloud. For taking this activity all Clearing Payment Documents has to be manually Reset and Reversed (FBRA).

Use the configuration SSC-UI 106107 Fix Errors for Payment Batches.

  1. Read the configuration help on the SSC-UI details page.
  2. Enable the functionality for "StatusFix" "AutoReject" "Mass Rest and Reversal" "AgentFix"

entry.title: Wildcard search within SuccessFactors rule
entry.content:
In SAP SuccessFactors, you cannot use wildcard characters like * or ? directly within the standard business rule expression language. However, there is powerful duo of Match function and regular expression in SuccessFactors, which achieves pattern-matching functionality and is a powerful alternative to traditional wildcard searches. 

Use cases for Regex in business rules:

  • Validation of fields: Ensure that the value of a field, such as a phone number, employee ID, or cost center, matches a specific format.
  • Checking string pattern: Verify that a string field begins, ends, or contains a certain pattern of characters.
  • Data integrity: Compare data in one field to see if it matches a pattern in another field or object.

Regex patterns for common wildcard needs:

  • To match a value that starts with a string: Use ^ to anchor the start of the string, followed by the desired text and .* to match any remaining characters.

  o Wildcard: HR02*

  o Regex: "^HR02.*"

  • To match a value that ends with a string: Use .* to match any preceding characters, followed by the desired text and $ to anchor the end of the string.

  o Wildcard: *Delhi

  o Regex: ".*Delhi$"

  • To match a value that contains a string: Use .* on both sides of the text you want to find.

  o Wildcard: *India*

  o Regex: ".*India.*"

  • To match a specific number of characters: Use . for a single character and {n} to specify the exact number of occurrences.

  o Wildcard: N?30

  o Regex: "N.30" (Matches N followed by any single character, then 30)

Sample Rules:

  1. Requirement was to have a string field to allow only year to be entered. Caveat was that the data type could not be changed as migrated data already existed on the field for a large set of population

  1. Requirement was to trigger a workflow only for capabilities which have HR02 or DO in their name. To make the rule future scalable, match and regex were used

 

  1. The requirement was to trigger rule for all the picklist values which have matrix manager as the non-unique external code. Though other string functions could also be used, but here is a sample with match and regex

Please Note:

While Regex offers great flexibility, complex patterns can impact system performance, particularly in onSave or onChange rules. Use simple and targeted patterns whenever possible.

Regex should be validated for the right pattern, I personally use regex101.com to validate it.

Cheatsheet for Regex tokens:

1. Literal Characters:
Any character that is not a special metacharacter (listed below) matches itself literally. For example, a matches the character 'a', and ab matches the string 'ab'.
2. Metacharacters:
  • Anchors:
    • ^: Matches the beginning of a string or line (when multiline flag m is used).
    • $: Matches the end of a string or line (when multiline flag m is used).
    • \b: Matches a word boundary.
    • \B: Matches a non-word boundary.
  • Quantifiers:
    • *: Matches zero or more occurrences of the preceding element.
    • +: Matches one or more occurrences of the preceding element.
    • ?: Matches zero or one occurrence of the preceding element.
    • {n}: Matches exactly n occurrences.
    • {n,}: Matches n or more occurrences.
    • {n,m}: Matches between n and m occurrences (inclusive).
  • Character Classes:
    • .: Matches any character except newline (unless dotAll flag s is used).
    • [abc]: Matches any one of the characters 'a', 'b', or 'c'.
    • [^abc]: Matches any character not 'a', 'b', or 'c'.
    • [a-z]: Matches any lowercase letter from 'a' to 'z'.
    • \d: Matches any digit (equivalent to [0-9]).
    • \D: Matches any non-digit.
    • \w: Matches any word character (alphanumeric and underscore, equivalent to [a-zA-Z0-9_]).
    • \W: Matches any non-word character.
    • \s: Matches any whitespace character (space, tab, newline, etc.).
    • \S: Matches any non-whitespace character.
     
    Alternation:
    • |: Matches either the expression before or after the |.
    Escaping:
    • `\`: Escapes a special metacharacter, treating it as a literal character. For example, \. matches a literal dot, and \* matches a literal asterisk.
    • \n, \t, \r, \f, \v: Special character escapes for newline, tab, carriage return, form feed, and vertical tab, respectively.

entry.title: Re: splitting 100000 records to two internal tables and post in al11
entry.content:
I don't know if your question is about splitting or uploading.

Let's assume it's about splitting. It's very simple ABAP code:

DATA(itab_1) = VALUE tt_itab( ( LINES OF itab FROM 1 TO 50000 ) ).
DATA(itab_2) = VALUE tt_itab( ( LINES OF itab FROM 50001 TO 100000 ) ).
